title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #353: Geometric Configurations in Infinite Measure Sets**

Let A ⊆ ℝ² have infinite Lebesgue measure. Must A contain vertices of:
- Isosceles trapezoid of area 1?
- Isosceles triangle of area 1?
- Right-angled triangle of area 1?

**Answer:** YES for all three (Koizumi 2025)

Parallelograms can fail (Kovač 2023 counterexample).
mathContext: This connects geometric measure theory with combinatorial geometry.

title: Infinite Measure Sets
content:
**HasInfiniteMeasure A:**

A set A ⊆ ℝ² satisfies:
1. A is Lebesgue measurable
2. volume(A) = ∞

Examples:
- The whole plane ℝ²
- Any half-plane
- Unbounded strips

Key: Infinite measure ensures sufficient density for configurations.
mathContext: Lebesgue measure extends the notion of area to irregular sets.

title: Triangle and Quadrilateral Area
content:
**triangleArea p q r:**

Area = |det([q-p, r-p])| / 2

Using the cross product formula:
|(q-p)₀·(r-p)₁ - (q-p)₁·(r-p)₀| / 2

**quadrilateralArea p q r s:**

Sum of areas of triangles (p,q,r) and (p,r,s).
mathContext: The shoelace formula generalizes to any simple polygon.

title: Isosceles Triangle
content:
**IsIsoscelesTriangle p q r:**

A triangle with at least two equal sides:
- dist(p,q) = dist(p,r), OR
- dist(p,q) = dist(q,r), OR
- dist(p,r) = dist(q,r)

The vertex opposite the unique side is the apex.

title: Right-Angled Triangle
content:
**IsRightTriangle p q r:**

A triangle with one 90° angle.

Detected via inner product = 0:
- inner(q-p, r-p) = 0 (right angle at p)
- inner(p-q, r-q) = 0 (right angle at q)
- inner(p-r, q-r) = 0 (right angle at r)
mathContext: The inner product being zero means perpendicular vectors.

title: Isosceles Trapezoid
content:
**IsIsoscelesTrapezoid p q r s:**

A quadrilateral with:
1. One pair of parallel sides (cross product = 0)
2. Equal non-parallel (leg) sides

**Key distinction from parallelogram:**
Trapezoid: ONE pair parallel
Parallelogram: BOTH pairs parallel

This difference is why parallelograms can fail but trapezoids work!
mathContext: Parallelism is detected via zero cross product.

title: Parallelogram
content:
**IsParallelogram p q r s:**

Both pairs of opposite sides are parallel and equal:
- q - p = r - s (top ∥ bottom)
- s - p = r - q (left ∥ right)

**Important:** Kovač showed parallelograms of area 1 need NOT exist in infinite measure sets!

title: Cyclic Quadrilateral
content:
**IsCyclicQuadrilateral p q r s:**

All four vertices lie on a common circle:
∃ center, radius > 0 such that:
- dist(center, p) = radius
- dist(center, q) = radius
- dist(center, r) = radius
- dist(center, s) = radius

Kovač-Predojević (2024): These always exist with area 1!

title: Koizumi's Theorems (2025)
content:
**koizumi_isosceles_trapezoid, koizumi_isosceles_triangle, koizumi_right_triangle:**

Every measurable set with infinite measure contains:
1. An isosceles trapezoid of area 1
2. An isosceles triangle of area 1
3. A right-angled triangle of area 1

This completely resolves Erdős Problem #353 for these shapes.

**Reference:** arXiv:2501.01914 (January 2025)
mathContext: The proof uses measure-theoretic density arguments.

title: Parallelogram Counterexample
content:
**kovac_parallelogram_counterexample:**

There EXISTS a set A with infinite measure such that A does NOT contain the vertices of any parallelogram with area 1.

This shows parallelograms are fundamentally different from trapezoids!

**Why?** Parallelograms have two parallel pairs, giving more constraints. The counterexample exploits this rigidity.

title: Cyclic Quadrilaterals Exist
content:
**kovac_predojevic_cyclic:**

Every set with infinite measure contains four points on a circle forming a quadrilateral of area 1.

**Reference:** Kovač-Predojević (2024) arXiv:2412.11725

title: Scaling Property
content:
**scaling_property:**

If infinite measure sets contain configurations of area 1, they contain configurations of ANY positive area t.

**Proof idea:** Scale the set by factor √t. The scaled set still has infinite measure, so it contains area-1 configurations. Scaling back gives area-t configurations in the original set.

title: Summary
content:
**Erdős Problem #353: SOLVED**

**Results:**
- Isosceles trapezoid: YES (Koizumi 2025)
- Isosceles triangle: YES (Koizumi 2025)
- Right triangle: YES (Koizumi 2025)
- Cyclic quadrilateral: YES (Kovač-Predojević 2024)
- Parallelogram: NO (counterexample exists)

**Key Insight:** One parallel pair (trapezoid) is weak enough to guarantee existence, but two parallel pairs (parallelogram) can fail.
